name: Josie
comment info:
1. We notice that the graphs are showing different amounts of money in various sizes of shapes (squares and rectangles in this case). We also notice that there are state and local paid, out of 745 billion dollars; there was only 400 million that went to election security even after all the publicity in the news for fraud and more compared to the other spending.
2. We wonder if the square of grants for colleges and universities will increase in the future since the cost of college is increasing. We wonder why there wasn't more spending for employee retention to increase the number of workers looking for jobs and more. We also wonder why the healthcare spending box is so small when COVID had a huge impact. Would more increased funding to healthcare have aided us more in the pandemic? 
3. Some of this money could have been used to help fix the supply chain, and businesses. This could have helped the economy get back to its “normal” state.
“Missing Billions? Where did it go?”

name: Sharon Hessney
comment info:
Welcome to Wednesday's live moderation of “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  

Today’s graphs show the federal funds that went to households, businesses large and small, local governments, schools and other institutions around the country for the two years from March 2020 to February 28, 2022.  The purpose of the $5 trillion stimulus infusion was to help Americans financially from the effects of the Covid-19 pandemic.   

From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, share with us your responses online to these three questions -- "What do you notice?”, “What do you wonder?"  and “How will this affect you and your community?”  Plus, please share with us a catchy headline that captures the ideas in these graphs. 

By Friday morning, we’ll reveal the article that included these graphs and much more.  We look forward to reading your discoveries.

Note that you can get a link to your response to share with your teacher and classmates by clicking the response box below your response “Email me when my comment is published.”  

Please visit our archive to see all graphs in this series (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphs).
View our archives that link to all past releases, organized by topic (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsTopicIndex), 
graph type (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsTypeIndex) and 
Stat Nugget (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsStatNuggetsIndex).  

The next “What’s Going On In This Graph?” will be released by Friday, April 15 with moderation on Wednesday, April 20.  The topic – U.S. population dynamics.

comment info:
1 - Health care is actually a pretty large portion of the budget, compared to other areas, however, considering this is in response to the pandemic, I would actually expect it to be even more. 
2 - The main things which I wonder are the impacts this will have on the federal budgets of fiscal year 2021 and onward. This may be only part of the changes we are seeing towards economic policy due to the pandemic.
3 - The most noticeable impacts are 1) the economic changes due to the pandemic itself and 2) the direct (but rather small on an individual level) stream of money coming in the form of stimulus checks. Other impacts, such as unemployment and inflation, can be attributed to some mix of both the pandemic itself, and the government's response to the pandemic. An interesting impact which I see is that many who have not lost their jobs have started investing in the stock market due to the stimulus checks. Due to us being in uncertain times, a lot of that has gone into large companies with relatively "safe" stocks. In my opinion, this leads to very low amounts of economic "stimulation", for it's cost in inflation.
4 - "Pandemic Response at a Glance."
